The best CRPG in video game history... 

And over the past 40 years, I've played other ones, one by one.

None of them come close to Roque Trader's RPG atmosphere...

It's neck and neck with a coupla other CRPGs but Rogue Trader is my favorite game in recent memory, particularly after a full season of DLC and the big 1.5 patch. 

Rogue Trader is a lengthy, meaty RPG, offering plenty of depth in the combat, character builds and reactive decisions on offer. Main characters aren't measured by simple good and evil but by dogmatic, iconoclast and heretic, with higher levels in one limiting the other two to lower levels. The characters are excellent, good and evil, and excellently voice acted. Environments are dark and creepy. Pawel Perepelica's soundtrack thrums and synths in all the most grimdark of ways. Rogue Trader is not a game that you pick up and throw away but a healthy feast that keeps you playing well after the credits have rolled. Highly recommended!

Warhammer 40K: Rogue Trader — A Masterclass in Grimdark Roleplay

Warhammer 40K: Rogue Trader is one of the finest CRPGs I’ve ever played. Owlcat didn’t just adapt the 40K universe — they brought it to life with a level of depth, consequence, and atmosphere that feels both authentic and monumental.

This game nails the essence of the 41st millennium: the weight of command, the razor-edge of faith and heresy, the thrill of discovery, and the crushing scale of the Imperium. Every decision hits hard. Every moment feels earned.

Characters & Companion Arcs

The companions are the heart of this game, and Owlcat outdid themselves. Each character has their own moral compass, emotional depth, and personal journey that feels entwined with your dynasty’s fate.

Ulfar is absolutely best bro — loyal, steadfast, honorable, and a grounding presence in a universe gone mad. Every scene with him feels authentic and earned. A true warrior-poet of Fenris.

Kibella? Best girl, without question. Her presence radiates intensity, mystery, and power, and her story is one of the most compelling emotional arcs Owlcat has ever written.

Kibella’s Romance Arc

Without spoiling a thing:
Her romance path is phenomenal.
It’s layered, surprising, heartfelt, and beautifully paced. It respects her character — fierce, proud, and deeply complex — and creates a connection that feels meaningful rather than forced. One of the most satisfying romance arcs in modern CRPGs.

Atmosphere & World-Building

The worlds you visit feel alive, dangerous, and sacred. Whether you're walking through cathedral-like voidship corridors or stepping onto hellish frontiers, the game captures the aesthetic and soul of 40K perfectly. The music and voice acting elevate every encounter.

Gameplay & Systems

Deep, crunchy mechanics? Check.
Tactical, satisfying turn-based combat? Absolutely.
Dynasty management, voidship battles, colony building, and moral decisions that echo across entire sectors? This game has it all.

Looking Toward the Future

Patch 1.5 shows just how committed the devs are, and the future DLC roadmap looks incredible.
And when Owlcat eventually steps into Dark Heresy?
If it carries even a fraction of Rogue Trader’s narrative brilliance, it’s going to be legendary.

Final Verdict:

10/10 — An unforgettable CRPG epic, filled with heart, darkness, triumph, and some of the best character writing in modern gaming.
Ulfar is best bro. Kibella is best girl. And I cannot wait for more.

I don't normally like games this long but I adored this whole thing from front to back, and I honestly would be ok with it being longer or the world map being bigger so there's more to explore. There is always something happening in this game. It may not be a traditional open world but I got lost in 3 hour side tangents from single warp jump events more times than I can remember. There's an incredible sense of forward momentum that carries throughout the entire length of the game. The end manages to stick the landing too. Do you like choice and consequence in RPGs? This game has more choices and more consequences than any other game I've played. You will make decisions in the first 20 minutes that will be relevant 90 hours later. 

The companions are my favorite in any CRPG I've played. They are all flawed and feel like real people. You do have influence over how their personality shapes up, but at major moments they will make their own decisions based on that influence, instead of you telling them what to do. They will argue with and dislike each other, and sometimes you will have to pick a side. They will make mistakes and you can choose whether you want to forgive them. I've seen people say that some of them don't really have an "arc" so to speak, which is true, but I don't think all of them needed one. I've grown kind of tired of how many modern RPGs have companion side quests that are some kind of grand "self discovery" where you are making all their choices for them. I got a lot more attached to these people for the fact that they were working through their own issues. They are who they are, interacting with them was fun, and they still have a variety of different endings. 

The underlying roleplay system is addictive too. It isn't nearly as complex as other Owlcat games, but it's still deep enough to have a ton of variety in play styles. You have a lot of options but it's hard to make a straight up bad character in this game, especially if you're playing on normal. At first it does feel kind of complex, but it isn't hard to get a grasp on. The fact that all of your options for each archetype are available on the list from the beginning makes it look intimidating, but it lets you plan out your build which is something I really appreciate. That drove me kinda crazy in BG3 because I wasn't familiar with DND 5e. The best thing to do is just read what you have available and then favorite the skills that look cool or that you want to build around and you'll be fine. Even if you don't do this and just kinda pick stuff when you feel like it you'll probably still be able to get through the game on normal. Gear itemization isn't as good as Diablo but this is the closest a non-ARPG has made me feel to that kind of experience. You can get very OP in this game. I don't know where else to mention this so I'll just say it here, I only had 1 bug in the entire time playing and it was patched mid-playthrough. No crashes or anything either.

The first DLC expansion, Void Shadows, is the best DLC in any game I've played. It's so intertwined with the main story and well written that I honestly wouldn't have been able to tell it was DLC if I didn't already know it was. It is seriously a highlight of this game. I wouldn't say the same about the 2nd DLC, Lex Imperialis. I think that one is worth buying purely for the mechanical stuff it adds. The gear it adds is fun and Arbites is a pretty great background to pick when you make your character. I didn't like the quest for it a ton though. It has it's moments but overall compared to the base game and especially Void Shadows it wasn't as good. I'm hesitant to call it straight up bad but out of the entire game it was definitely the low point. 

Finally, the main story. It is good. I was a 40k fan going in so I wasn't ever lost in terms of lore, but I think this game does a pretty good job of explaining whats relevant in way that a newcomer could understand. Having meta knowledge of the setting did allow me to figure out some things before my character did, and that was pretty fun. I would be curious to see how someone who is completely new would handle some of these choices. In terms of 40k games there's a massive variety of stuff to see here. I don't want to spoil it because a lot of it was pretty surprising to me and going in blind is really fun. A good chunk of the companion quests are pretty heavily interlinked with the main story in a satisfying way. The plot it's self is intriguing and they do a good job of tying everything together at the end. This game spins a lot of plates at once. Once I started following the different breadcrumb trails and trying to piece everything together I got hooked and couldn't stop playing. In general this game is very reactive in ways that will sneak up on you or that you might not even realize. When a decision directly affects something and it comes up in dialogue, it's highlighted in blue and when you hover over it it'll tell you what you did. The thing is, there's a lot of times where the direct effect doesn't come up in dialogue. There's times you won't know what you're watching is because of something you did. There's missable interactions that lead to plot revelations or even different endings. Sometimes those secret endings are even different depending on what choices you make throughout the game. There was a time where I did part of a companion quest that went completely fine and when I looked it up after, it turned out there was several other pretty drastic outcomes that I wouldn't have even known about if I hadn't looked it up on a whim. This game is massively replayable in that respect.

Overall, I loved this game. It's the most fun I've had with an RPG since Fallout New Vegas and maybe even since Fallout 1. I highly recommend doing what I did and starting the game in Grimdark mode. This is basically a permadeath mode where you're locked to 1 save, but if you die then you can just continue the save in normal mode. I'm definitely guilty of save scumming in most RPGs or reloading my save to see how different dialogue options play out. Being committal in this game really lends its self to the sense that you are leading these people through this crisis. When the mode is active the combat is a lot more tense too. I made it about 53 hours in before dying, and I enjoyed it so much that I self imposed the no reloads rule for the entire rest of the playthrough. That is definitely how I'm playing all future RPGs going forward. I need to play the pathfinder games now. I cannot wait for the new DLC for this game as well. It's going to be centered around an egotistical archaeologist necron lord named Trazyn (my favorite character in the whole setting), and exploring his planet sized gallery. It is going to be 40k night in the museum and it'll rule. Dark Heresy will be a day one purchase when it comes out. Owlcat went god mode with this game and they have a new fan.

Gameplay: 9/10. This game is turn based and you have NO IDEA how freeing and easy to understand this game's stats and archetypes turned out to be after the    N I G H T M A R E   that was Pathfinder's character building. You get to pick your homeworld type, your origin, an archetype, your stats, what was your biggest achievement and your worst moment and all of these details change your stats, influence your build and even give you dialogue choices and world reactivity. It may seem daunting at first, trust me, but it's a lot more digestible when you get to the action! The only reason I don't give it a 10 is because this game has some seriously boneheaded bosses that are just plain not fun to fight due to poorly made design choices... (You'll know what i'm talking about when you get to them)

Visuals: 8/10 The game is GORGEOUS. Warhammer settings, monsters, warp abominations, ships and architecture are recreated wonderfully in the game. Even if it's an isometric perspective game, it doesn't spare details on the character models, vehicles and map/level design. It DOES however really heat up your machines and the game can stutter at times, which I don't really understand why...we're not playing Cyberpunk, it's a turn-based Isometric RPG....And unfortunately, I have to deduct a point for what i'm about to say (and i know it's gonna sound like nitpick) but why can't we have more augment options? Where are the fancy robotic eyes and prosthetic legs and limbs? I know, we're not gonna hit Tech-Mage levels of metal but we could have gotten some cooler options...

Overrall, I'd give this game a 9.5/10. It's a fantastic choice for anyone wanting to get into the world of Warhammer 40k, and it's magnificent to know that not only are the developers still putting updates and small bugfixes into this game, but they're taking everything they learned and making ANOTHER Warhammer CRPG! Great game with a few blemishes. It's a hard one to recommend for everyone as lots of people will no doubt be turned off by these faults, but for Owlcat fans, RPG fans, and even Warhammer fans, I think it's worth a shot. 

First I have to say that the writing and immersion into Warhammer 40k is top notch here, without a doubt one of the best of any Warhammer game. As an RPG it's also fantastic, VERY deep character builds and lots and lots of choices to make throughout, especially among good and evil. You do feel like a ruler by the end, with multiple colonies, armies, and power over civilizations. It's a game that's begging to be played multiple times and that's great.

For the downsides, the game still has rough edges. The balance is ridiculous, even after recent updates, it's still insane. The first two chapters feel about right and I managed to play well enough on medium difficulty, but once chapter 3 hits and especially in chapters 4 and 5 it just goes nuts. Enemies have multiple attacks per round, multiple health bars, prerequisites before they can be damaged etc. It stops being fun and just gets exhausting as chapters 3, 5, and most of 4 are almost pure combat. I knocked the game down to story difficulty, maybe could have done the one above it, but again, just exhausting. It's balanced around grinding for the best gear, optimized builds, and perfect tactical play, which I guess is great for those wanting a challenge, but it was a lot for me.

Same can be said for ship combat, which at first I hated and didn't think it should exist in a game like this, but I've come around to like it a little more by the end of the game. It's just balanced poorly and far too difficult since your options for ship gear and abilities are far more limited than in ground combat.

Finally I'll say this is a minor quibble, but while the game is super epic on a galactic Warhammer scale, I feel taking a regular person starting the game with a revolver and growing them so powerful that you wipe entire Drukhari Kabals, Chaos Space Marine squads, Chaos Gods, and every type of Necron diminishes the power of these entities in the lore. Not that you shouldn't encounter and defeat these groups, just that you alone shouldn't be able to do it. I guess once again it's a balance issue...

[h1]Warhammer 40,000: Rogue Trader[/h1]
Let me start out with:
I have never explored into the Warhammer 40k universe before (other than Total War) so Warhammer 40,000: Rogue Trader is my first dive.
Now, I know there a ton of "top-down CRPG story games" out there, but only a few of them had a story that really stuck (with me). I needed something that was different - something new.
And let me tell you: the Warhammer 40k universe? It's different.
In the best way.
[i]Also, this review is a scatterbrained collection of things I liked about the game. There are a ton of other reviews listing pros and cons if that's more your fancy.[/i]

[h2]Soundtrack[/h2]
I spent an ungodly amount of time with this game idle in the background. I'd get on to play but end up getting sidetracked and spiraling into production-mode with the music playing in the background (which I later [url=https://store.steampowered.com/app/2682660/Warhammer_40000_Rogue_Trader__Deluxe_Pack/?curator_clanid=43222021]bought the soundtrack[/url] just to support the devs and get it in FLAC). The point is - I didn't want to leave the world. It may be seeping with corruption; but it's a soothing lullaby in the real world of corruption and darkness beyond the screen. From hearing the tracks in the space map to the echoes of duty from the bridge - the soundtrack in this game really is amazing.

[h2]Writing[/h2]
[h3]Power Fantasy Trope[/h3]
Let's talk about the power fantasy trope and how it's done right. You are a Rouge Trader with supreme authority. In a world of darkness and chaos, you have the illusion of power. Your choices will impact the lives of billions living under you (and the story). You'll navigate politics, faction relations and affairs of foreign races. You'll feel the weight of your power - or abandon it to chaos (if you choose to go down that route).

[h3]Companions[/h3]
Ohhh, the companions. One of the best parts of this game imo. They're well written and each unique; it genuinely feels fun to explore your companion's stories as they accompany you across the Expanse.

[h3]Written Visuals[/h3]
Being a somewhat isometric game, most of the visuals you'll be getting is via written descriptions. As someone who never explored the 40k universe before, when reading some of the descriptions, I was shocked, disgusted, and in awe - and sometimes all three. This really is one of those games where you have to see it inside your head to actually feel it; and Rogue Trader's writing style allows you to do that. I felt compelled to read every line. They were oozing with sickening detail that I was eating up like gravy.

[h2]Gameplay[/h2]
It acts pretty similar to games in the genre. And that's not necessarily a bad thing. Why break something that works, right? Although, it can get repetitive towards the end (like most CRPGS!). it's fun for the bulk of the game when you're learning the systems and assembling your party.
[h3]Progression and Character Building[/h3]
There are a ton of different skills and a multitude of ways to build your characters. If you avoid online guides, you'll spend hours in the progression menus. The combat can become pretty easy if you build your characters right and synergize the party. So, as always, abuse moderately :)
[h3]Combat[/h3]
Something I liked about the combat is that every sequence had a story. I never really felt like I was crawling through a dungeon and wiping out mobs for the sake of killing things; each encounter had a story (and usually) a conversation behind it.

=================
[h1]Summary[/h1]
It will be hard for me to forget my experience with this game. I went into it with minor expectations and was enthralled by the world and characters within it. The Warhammer 40k lore was a blast to learn & experience through Rouge Trader.

I'm currently ticking up to 90 hours now in game, here are my thoughts:

SETTING:
I really enjoy 40k as dark universe, but something which bugs me about it is how much of it focused on the imperium of man, I get it, they are humans which is something we can relate to, (if one can relate to what becomes of human culture in 40k) but the imperium is only 1 of many different xeno species which inhabit the universe is what is meant to be a all out war.
This game doesn't quite have that feel, at least not yet at where I am in the game.

Quite often I'm dealing with issues within the imperium itself, dealing with criminal Gangs, uprisings, corruption and difference of opinion.
Now interacting with aliens (aka Xenos) does happen, rarely but it does happen, it feels like 1/10 missions relate to xeno's which gets me excited when it finally occours.
Choas also plays big part in it too, perhaps more than I'd like, but they make a good enemy, they are in it about 1/3 missions.

Sometimes I feel like the game is deliberately taking the piss as there is literally one mission when you have to wait in a que to get administration paperwork done... That's not why people go into games workshop for.

there are some missions which I find to be absolute gems... but for me it can feel like a slog to get to and you may never know until you'll hit it.

and there is ALOT OF content, which is good.

GAMEPLAY:
So the game doesn't have a lot of hand holding, there is information available, but I feel like there is Too much information to learn how to play a game. no one likes to read technical manuals to entertain themselves.

I'm still learning how to do some things, but I'm feeling like I got the majority of what I need to know, once you know it becomes pretty easy to remember.

Some of the character abilities are confusing, and the explanation doesn't really help either. most of them are just buffing abilities you use before you make your attack, it makes building a character a bit trickier, you could spend hours and hours researching what each ability does and still only scratch the surface.

The gameplay has xcom style vibe to it as well as owlcats other pathfinder games. so if you played either of them you know what you're in for.

encounters can be tricky at times with a lot of fights too easy and the occasional super hard one, but overall i haven't hard to much difficulty progressing. 

the game has puzzles too which owlcat studios don't have the greatest reputation for, but fortunately most of them aren't mandatory and there are plenty of online walkthroughs you can use if you get stuck, i definately used some in a few instances and don't regret it.

STORY:
the story is superb, I know this may seem contradictory to my comments about the missions but there is a significant difference between the two. The mission generally consists of getting the plot device or dealing with a 
a antagonist, the story is why you are doing this things which i think the game handles well, the characters in the game is what brings it all to life, with these characters you actually become to be able to relate to what it is actually like living in the 40k universe and my god it's a mad house of gut wrenching drama on all levels.
even the minor NPC'S you may only encounter once add so much to the experience. 
Just to give a brief example of one character explaining the ingredients of what they use as 'soup' to feed the less fortunate crew members of your own ship, he offered me a bowl... I declined. and made damn sure they were fed properly afterwards.

That said, Sometimes the Text of the game gets a bit heavy, and I'm finding myself skipping through alot of it... it depends on my mood, usually I'll skim read it to see if anything jumps out at at me at the worst of times. 

OVERALL:
This may not be the most glowing review, but I'm still giving it a thumbs up.
I don't regret the purchase or it's DLC (which I recommend getting for first time buyers) , 
it's got plenty of story, action, intrigue and content to occupy you for a month.

This game was sold as a cooperative game, but this is a lie. While act 1 is somewhat playable co-op, the second player will frequently be left behind. This happens for the first time during the games first morality check, which will always leave player 2 behind unpassable barriers. This will keep happening. Depending on your group composition (officers and cassia are biggest offenders) you might be able to make it almost halfway through act 1 before the real problem begins to show its head, the deadly desync.

This game desyncs constantly. The inbuilt pauses to warn you of traps or found loot will desync you. Any sort of extra turn action in combat will desync you. Most aoe has a reasonable chance of desync. Reloading from said desync also takes far too long. Neither really do anything about what you are doing despite saying "I'm installing a known heretic into a position of power" or "In the name of my Dark Master, I will sacrifice your entire colony". A well designed game should feature a series of gradually escalating challenges, with regular checks to make sure you are mastering the various mechanics and game systems, culminating in a final test that puts it all together.

Rogue Trader is, unfortunately, not a well designed game.

That is not to say it is not a [i]fun[/i] game. But the developers have created such a poorly balanced system that they are unable to create meaningful challenges without ignoring or negating game mechanics, and the final series of bosses does not test the player's mastery over the tactical gameplay, but instead how broken their character builds are. If you are not able to put out several [b]thousand[/b] points of damage in a single round (a damage check that is not seen [i]anywhere else in the game[/i]) then you will find yourself stuck with your only recourse being to reload a save from several hours prior and respec your entire team.

If you're fine with an experience that is 90% enjoyable but completely shits the bed in the last 10% (or, are a Warhammer fan and are used to dealing with a product that is compromised in some way) then I think you will probably find this game to be worth it, but I can't say it is a product I would [i]recommend[/i].

Now, a minute or two load time seems not so bad, but then you realize this will start happening more and more frequently. By act 2, expect 1 desync a round. Let e just start by saying I've played a lot of Top Down Turn Based RPG from Tyranny, to Torment, from BG3, to ones that I can barely remember in the classic D&D genre. Rogue Trader is a game that if you are familiar with 40K, you will probably really enjoy, but for me it was a swing and a miss. I loved Space marines as a kid, but never really grew into the lore, etc.

If you are expecting BG3 levels of chracter connection, it's nowhere near the mark. There's barely any romance in this which always felt like a bonus in other games of similar style. Instead you have a world that if it's unfamiliar will force you to try and remember complex character names, and titles. Read through endless dialogue that just doesn't feel natural or relatable.

It felt more like a slog, than an immersive experience. Instead of starting you off with a nobody, you are almost immediately thrust into one of the most powerful positions in the game, and the trade off is you often don't feel like you care about the development of the character you are playing. Also, if you are expecting a trade game, it's not that either as there's no money system.

In comparison to the majority of titles out there, it's not geared towards new players, it has a completely disjointed way of playing, and although more interesting than a lot of others, it doesn't hit the mark for me. I can see why it would for others though.

It starts strong, but everything after Act 1 it becomes is sooooo boring. The game will routinely waste your time with needless animation in exploration and planet scanning for little bits of nothing. It's fun for a while, but it gets very old, very quick. 

As for positives, it absolutely nails the aesthetic and has multiple builds that actually work (mostly due to Rogue Trader being a less bloated system than Pathfinder), and offers far more tactical approaches other than "pre-buff and nuke". Dedicated tanks are actually a thing. The sounds are also on point for the most part, with the biggest issue being the players own voice. 

Some options are good, but most are terrible. Funnily enough, there are more male voices than Female (6 vs 5), with none of the old Pathfinder voices making a return, which can make finding a voice to matches your character really hard.

Ship battles are terrible. They are slow, they are boring, they don't really allow you be tactical, and you seem to ALWAYS go last regardless of circumstance, and you CAN be attacked on the first turn. This has lead to my ship being in a fairly dire position before I can even do anything. 

Speaking of not doing anything...my character is going down the heretic path. It's not well structured, it's cartoon  levels of evil. There is no subtlety of Slaanesh, no grand plan of Tzentch. It's very surface level "Blood for the Blood God". But worst of all, you have a Sister of Battle and an Inquisitor. Neither really do anything about what you are doing despite saying "I'm installing a known heretic into a position of power" or "In the name of my Dark Master, I will sacrifice your entire colony". The companions just...don't react, and you are really given any companions that really make a heretical playthrough worth while. There isn't a companion that I've actually really liked. There just...all the same dogmatic "Imperial Truth", "Xeno's should all be murdered". I miss the grumpy dwarf, or the scheming spider-cat.

To fix this, all that is needed would be an option where you could a "Dogmatic" approach in "cleansing heresy", though in secret you could be offering up their souls to Khorne. It matters not from where the blood flows. Small things like that would help me feel as though my character was actually a heretic.

And the bugs, because it wouldn't be an Owlcat game if the game had fewer bugs than Bethesda.

If you are interested, pick it up on heavy discount like I did, but expect the fantasy to wear off very quickly, and hearing things like "Everything up till the end of Act 3 is fine" does not inspire confidence.
